hypotheses.title: ClickFix DNS Tunneling via nslookup for Malware Staging
hypotheses.description: Threat actors are evolving the ClickFix social engineering campaign to use the built-in Windows `nslookup` utility to retrieve malicious payloads via DNS TXT records, bypassing traditional PowerShell and `mshta` blocks. This hypothesis hunts for users executing `nslookup` commands against suspicious domains followed by immediate PowerShell or script execution, indicating a staged malware delivery.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs, command-line arguments, parent-child process relationships
DNS query logs (TXT records), DNS response sizes

hunting_tactics.description: Search for `nslookup` executions where the query type is TXT and the domain is not a standard internal or known external service, followed by PowerShell execution.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_logs ProcessName="nslookup.exe" | search CommandLine="* -type=txt *" | stats count by User, Host, CommandLine | where count > 1

KQL (Sentinel): DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "nslookup.exe" | where CommandLine contains "-type=txt" | join kind=leftouter (DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "powershell.exe" | where TimeGenerated > ago(5m)) on $left.User == $right.User | project TimeGenerated, User, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: Users running `nslookup` with `-type=txt` against random-looking domains, immediately followed by `powershell.exe` or `cmd.exe` spawning a script.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify DNS TXT queries that return unusually large payloads (base64 encoded scripts) which are typical for this staging technique.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=dns_logs qtype="TXT" | eval payload_len=len(qry) | where payload_len > 200 | stats count by src_ip, qry
Elasticsearch: GET /dns-logs/_search { "query": { "bool": { "must": [ { "match": { "qtype": "TXT" } }, { "range": { "response_size": { "gt": 200 } } } ] } }
hunting_tactics.look_for: TXT record responses containing Base64 strings or executable code snippets.

other_indicators: Social engineering prompts asking users to 'copy and paste' commands into Run dialog

recommended_actions: Isolate affected endpoints immediately.
Block DNS TXT queries to unknown external domains at the firewall.
Scan for ModeloRAT or similar RAT artifacts on the host.
Reset credentials for the compromised user account.

hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise via Malicious OpenClaw and AI Agent Configurations
hypotheses.description: Attackers are targeting the emerging ecosystem of local AI agents (specifically OpenClaw) by distributing malicious 'skills' or compromised npm packages (e.g., Cline CLI) that install infostealers. This hypothesis hunts for the installation of unauthorized AI agent configurations, exfiltration of AI identity files, and connections to known malicious C2 infrastructure associated with these tools.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1567.002 - Exfiltration Over Web Service: Web Service
T1055.012 - Process Injection: Process Hollowing
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File system changes, new processes spawning from npm/node, network connections from AI agent processes
NPM package installation logs, CI/CD pipeline logs

hunting_tactics.description: Search for processes accessing or exfiltrating files associated with OpenClaw or similar AI agents (e.g., config files, API keys, memory dumps).
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_logs (ProcessName="node.exe" OR ProcessName="python.exe") | search CommandLine="*OpenClaw*" OR CommandLine="*clawdbot*" | stats count by User, Host
KQL: DeviceFileEvents | where FileName has "OpenClaw" or FileName has "clawdbot" | where Operation == "Write" or Operation == "Delete" | project TimeGenerated, FileName, User, DeviceName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unusual file access patterns targeting `~/.openclaw`, `~/.clawdbot`, or similar directories, especially followed by network egress.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify installations of known malicious packages (e.g., fake Oura MCP servers, compromised Cline CLI) or packages with suspicious dependencies.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=ci_cd_logs | search action="install" AND (package="cline" OR package="oura-mcp" OR package="openclaw") | stats count by user, repository

KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "npm" or ProcessName == "yarn" | where CommandLine contains "install" | where CommandLine contains "openclaw" or CommandLine contains "cline" | project TimeGenerated, CommandLine, User
hunting_tactics.look_for: Installation of packages named 'cline', 'oura-mcp', or 'openclaw' from non-official registries or by non-authorized developers.

network_patterns: Outbound connections to AI agent C2 domains
POST requests to AI provider APIs with stolen tokens
other_indicators: Exfiltration of `.env` files containing AI API keys
Modification of `package.json` to include malicious dependencies

recommended_actions: Block network access to known malicious AI agent C2 domains.
Audit all developer machines for unauthorized npm packages.
Revoke and rotate any exposed AI API keys or tokens.
Isolate systems showing signs of OpenClaw configuration theft.

hypotheses.title: Active Exploitation of BeyondTrust and Ivanti RCE Vulnerabilities
hypotheses.description: CISA has added critical vulnerabilities in BeyondTrust (CVE-2026-1731) and Ivanti (CVE-2026-1281, CVE-2026-1340) to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Threat actors are actively exploiting these flaws to deploy VShell, SparkRAT, and other backdoors. This hypothesis focuses on detecting unauthenticated access attempts and subsequent lateral movement from these specific management consoles.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1021.001 - Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
T1078 - Valid Accounts

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Authentication logs, process creation from management consoles, web shell uploads
HTTP/S traffic to management ports (8443, 443), SQL injection patterns

hunting_tactics.description: Monitor for HTTP requests to BeyondTrust or Ivanti endpoints that result in 200 OK responses without prior authentication, indicating a successful exploit.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=web_logs (host="beyondtrust" OR host="ivanti") | search status=200 AND (uri="/api/*" OR uri="/rest/*") | where NOT (user_agent="*Mozilla*" OR user_agent="*Chrome*") | stats count by src_ip, uri

KQL: CommonSecurityLog | where ProductName == "BeyondTrust" or ProductName == "Ivanti" | where Result == "Success" and AuthenticationStatus == "Unauthenticated" | project TimeGenerated, SourceIP, TargetIP, Action
hunting_tactics.look_for: Successful HTTP requests to sensitive API endpoints without valid session tokens or cookies.

hunting_tactics.description: Search for the creation of suspicious files (web shells) in web directories of management servers immediately following an exploit attempt.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_logs (ProcessName="iis.exe" OR ProcessName="apache2") | search FileName="*.php" OR FileName="*.asp" OR FileName="*.jsp" | where Directory="*webroot*" OR Directory="*htdocs*" | stats count by FileName, Host

KQL: DeviceFileEvents | where FileName has "vshell" or FileName has "sparkrat" or FileName has "webshell" | where Path contains "inetpub" or Path contains "htdocs" | project TimeGenerated, FileName, Path, User
hunting_tactics.look_for: New PHP, ASP, or JSP files created in web directories, specifically named `vshell`, `sparkrat`, or generic names like `admin.php`.

recommended_actions: Immediately patch BeyondTrust and Ivanti systems to the latest versions.
Block all inbound traffic to management ports from untrusted networks.
Scan web directories for web shells and remove them.
Reset all administrative credentials for these systems.

hypotheses.title: Fake Job Recruitment Campaigns Targeting Developers with Malicious Repos
hypotheses.description: Threat actors (including Lazarus Group) are using fake job recruitment lures to distribute malicious npm and PyPI packages or GitHub repositories. These lures often appear as technical assessments or Next.js projects that, when cloned or installed, execute backdoors or steal secrets. This hypothesis hunts for developers interacting with suspicious repositories or installing packages from unknown sources.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Git clone commands, npm install logs, execution of scripts from temp directories
Phishing emails containing job offers, links to GitHub/npm

hunting_tactics.description: Identify developers cloning repositories with names related to job interviews, assessments, or popular frameworks (Next.js) from non-official sources.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_logs ProcessName="git.exe" | search CommandLine="*clone*" AND (CommandLine="*job*" OR CommandLine="*assessment*" OR CommandLine="*nextjs*" OR CommandLine="*interview*") | stats count by User, Host, CommandLine

KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "git.exe" | where CommandLine contains "clone" | where CommandLine contains "job" or CommandLine contains "assessment" | project TimeGenerated, CommandLine, User, DeviceName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Git clone commands targeting repositories with names like 'nextjs-job-test', 'coding-challenge', or 'assessment' from suspicious domains.

hunting_tactics.description: Detect the installation of npm or PyPI packages that are typosquatted or have suspicious dependencies, often linked to the 'graphalgo' or 'cline' campaigns.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_logs ProcessName="npm" | search CommandLine="*install*" AND (CommandLine="*graphalgo*" OR CommandLine="*cline*" OR CommandLine="*oura*" OR CommandLine="*fake*") | stats count by User, Host

KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "npm" or ProcessName == "pip" | where CommandLine contains "install" | where CommandLine contains "graphalgo" or CommandLine contains "cline" | project TimeGenerated, CommandLine, User
hunting_tactics.look_for: Installation of packages with names resembling legitimate tools but with slight variations, or packages with no downloads/low reputation.

other_indicators: Emails with subject lines like 'Job Opportunity', 'Technical Assessment', 'Coding Challenge'

recommended_actions: Block access to suspicious GitHub repositories and npm packages.
Scan developer environments for unauthorized packages.
Educate developers on the risks of cloning unverified repositories.
Revoke any API keys or secrets potentially exposed by the malicious packages.

hypotheses.title: ShinyHunters Data Exfiltration and Extortion via Third-Party Compromise
hypotheses.description: The ShinyHunters group is actively targeting organizations (e.g., Odido, CarGurus, Wynn Resorts) via third-party vendor compromises or credential stuffing, leading to massive data leaks and extortion. This hypothesis hunts for signs of unauthorized access to customer databases, unusual data exfiltration volumes, and communication with known ShinyHunters infrastructure.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1078 - Valid Accounts
T1021.001 - Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Authentication logs, MFA bypass attempts, unusual login locations
Large data transfers, connections to known leak sites

hunting_tactics.description: Detect multiple failed login attempts followed by a successful login from a new location or device, indicative of credential stuffing.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=auth_logs | search status="failed" | stats count as fail_count by user, src_ip | where fail_count > 5 | join kind=leftouter (index=auth_logs | search status="success" | stats count by user, src_ip) on user | where fail_count > 5

KQL: SigninLogs | where ResultType == 50166 or ResultType == 50053 | summarize FailedAttempts=count() by UserPrincipalName, IPAddress | join kind=inner (SigninLogs | where ResultType == 0 | summarize SuccessAttempts=count() by UserPrincipalName, IPAddress) on UserPrincipalName | where FailedAttempts > 5
hunting_tactics.look_for: High volume of failed logins followed by a successful login, especially from a different geographic location.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify unusually large data transfers from customer databases or file servers, particularly to external IPs or cloud storage.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=network_logs | search action="transfer" AND (protocol="SFTP" OR protocol="HTTP" OR protocol="HTTPS") | eval size_kb=bytes/1024 | where size_kb > 100000 | stats sum(size_kb) as total_kb by src_ip, dst_ip, user
KQL: NetworkTraffic | where Direction == "Outbound" | where BytesSent > 100000000 | summarize TotalBytes=sum(BytesSent) by SourceIp, DestinationIp, User
hunting_tactics.look_for: Large volume data transfers (e.g., >100MB) from internal databases to external IPs, especially during off-hours.

network_patterns: HTTP POST requests to leak sites

recommended_actions: Immediately revoke compromised credentials and enforce MFA.
Block traffic to known ShinyHunters leak sites and Telegram channels.
Isolate affected databases and investigate the scope of data exfiltration.
Prepare a communication plan for potential data breach notification.

unique_mitre_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1567.002 - Exfiltration Over Web Service: Web Service
T1021.001 - Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
